awd_titl_txt: WoU-MMA: Collaborative Research: A Next-Generation SuperNova Early Warning System for Multimessenger Astronomy
awd_abstract_narration:
When a massive star reaches the end of its life, the core of the star collapses, producing a supernova. While visually spectacular, less than 1% of the energy in the supernova is released as visible light or as kinetic energy in the surrounding environment. Most of the energy from the supernova is carried away by neutrinos produced during the collapse of the core.  In contrast to photons, neutrinos interact only very weakly with matter.  They can therefore stream out of the supernova explosion without delay and thus arrive at Earth minutes to hours before the optical explosion may be visible. Detecting the first neutrinos from a supernova therefore provides an early alert to trigger further observations. The SuperNova Early Warning System (SNEWS) is a network of neutrino detectors around the world designed to provide automated early alerts for supernovae in our galaxy. While rare, a galactic supernova would provide a unique opportunity to study the physics of core-collapse supernova, as well as the properties of neutrinos. Alerts from SNEWS will enable observations of the earliest phases of the supernova for physicists and astronomers around the world. The SNEWS project works to engage amateur astronomers by involving them in this science, as they play an important role in optical observations of supernova.

This award supports a collaborative group from several institutions to upgrade the existing SNEWS real-time alert system to include new detectors, and to prepare to better exploit the collective capabilities of these detectors.  The team will model neutrino light curves and use those models to evaluate the expected signals in all available neutrino detectors.  They will develop optimal methods for prompt determination of the supernova direction using both neutrino interaction anisotropies, as well as inter-experiment triangulation algorithms which will be based on relative observed timing of the neutrino signals.  Prompt directional information will sharply improve the likelihood to detect the early onset of the light curve in multiple channels.  This is crucial not only for the understanding of supernova explosions, but also for many other areas of physics including astrophysics, nuclear physics, and particle physics.  Finally they will develop pre-supernova alerts based on the observation of the uptick in neutrino production that accompanies the final burning stages of a doomed star.  This proposal also supports involvement of the amateur astronomy community in this exciting area  of research, the creation of a topical planetarium show, as well as a smartphone app for use in education and alert dissemination.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Background: as stars use up their internal fuel they eventually fade. But for massive stars, their eventual fates are marked by the collapse of their cores and the trigger of powerful explosions called supernovae. A single supernova outshines entire galaxies. Yet the supernova is still only a tiny piece of the whole picture. Hidden beneath the layers of the star, neutrinos---neutral particles that rarely interact---are produced in copious numbers and freely escape from the densest parts of the collapsing core. The neutrinos are emitted before the supernova, because the neutrinos freely escape while the supernova only emerges once the supernova shock breaks through the star's surface. In 1987, these neutrinos were detected for the first time from the nearby supernova, SN1987A. This confirmed the core collapse of a massive star, but still left many questions unanswered. Looking to the future, nearby supernovae occur roughly every 50-100 years, so they are rare and it is incredibly important that the community is prepared to exploit the rich data that could be collected for the benefit of science and humanity. This requires not only patience but coordinated effort to bridge the communities of neutrinos, astronomy, and gravitational waves. Fortunately, we have the ideal system to make this happen: active monitoring with a network of neutrino-sensitive detectors, which would automatically send out rapid alerts to the rest of the communities when a burst of neutrinos is registered across multiple detectors. This is the Supernova Neutrino Early Warning System (SNEWS) which aims to alert the world of the next supernova associated with the collapse of a nearby massive star. 

Intellectual Merit: the SNEWS2.0 collaboration was formed to deliver a major upgrade to the original SNEWS, focusing on the new era of multi-messenger astronomy. More specifically, SNEWS2.0 is a collection of efforts to expand the network of participating neutrino-sensitive detectors, to provide information on the localization of the supernova, and to better connect to the wide range of multi-messenger facilities capable of following-up on SNEWS alerts. With this award, efforts at Virginia Tech have contributed to neutrino signal predictions, neutrino pointing testing, and to the preparation of a list of supernova candidate stars in the Milky Way galaxy. Exploiting the list of supernova candidate stars, Virginia Tech contributed to the design of the global follow-up coordination that would occur following a future SNEWS2.0 alert to most efficiently identify the exploding star. In parallel, Virginia Tech also used the list of supernova candidates to implement improved monitoring of nearby candidate stars through coordination with the telescopes (professional and amateur) including those associated with the American Association of Variable Star Observers. Together, monitoring and follow-up would enhance the prospects of obtaining detailed measurements of the next supernova, from before the explosion to after. 

Broader Impact: outreach to the broader scientific community, amateur astronomers, and to the public more generally, are crucial and intimately connected to the core intellectual efforts of SNEWS2.0. Graduate students were trained in the inter-disciplinary intersection of astrophysics and neutrino physics. We also formed a strong collaboration with the American Association of Variable Star Observers, which resulted in the implementation of a special monitoring campaign of supernova candidate stars identified by efforts at Virginia Tech. A new website (snews2.org) was created to inform the professional and general public about the SNEWS2.0 effort and further disseminated future alerts. Results from this award were also included in material taught at Virginia Tech's advanced course on astroparticle physics.
